Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Compact Ultra High Resolution 360 Degree Imaging System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will advance the state of the art in the design of optics for 360-degree real-time staring panoramic cameras. Current approaches to providing wide angle optics for cameras are based on lenses and mirrors that are limited in design by optimization methods based on traditional optics where optical field compression, in addition to residual aberration and mirror conic constants are used in optimization. This results in relatively large optics relative to digital sensor size as well as low resolution at wide angles. In this project, a theoretical framework for aberration correction in wide angle optics considering field compression as a driving constraint will be investigated, with a goal at achieving optics sizes close to the size of the digital sensors that they are designed for. This will be done by introducing field compression constraints in an existing optical design package and modifying the optimization path by introducing approaches for off axis ray aiming. It is anticipated that the Phase I work will result in a modified optics optimization package for designing ultra-wide angle compact optics for digital sensors. A concept optics design demonstrating the features of the package will be demonstrated.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be in broadening availability of wide angle high resolution systems for a number of defense, homeland security and commercial markets. The development of an optimization tool for compact wide angle optics with high digital resolution at extreme angles of incidence will enable future developments of tools for compact wide angle adaptively variable resolutions, opening up the space of available solutions for wide area imagery. The project seeks to determine the influence of number, shape and arrangement of key optical surfaces on size, quality and resolution, and the impact on cost and scalability. This will have a broader impact on the optical design community as it will provide a framework to develop optical systems that demonstrate optical quality without sacrificing digital resolution. Applications such as persistent wide area surveillance, vehicle 360- degree situational awareness, wide angle video conferencing and webcams will benefit from this research. The availability of ultra-wide angle high resolution camera systems has the potential to better exploit the growth path of ever smaller high resolution digital image sensors with new potential consumer applications such as cameras on televisions and inexpensive wide angle cameras for surveillance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High resolution ultra-wide angle (360 degree) optics are becoming increasingly important in a number of applications ranging from military vehicles to consumer videoconferencing solutions. The use of convex conic mirror based optics has resulted in the realization of very high resolution ultra-wide angle camera systems, with pixel resolutions of up to 100 Megapixels for ultra-wide angle video systems and up to Gigapixel resolution for scanning systems. The use of single view point parabolic and hyperbolic mirrors provide additional benefits such as minimizing optical aberrations and providing the basis of pure geometrical transformations for low power image processing. A fundamental limitation in these systems has been the size of the optics in relation to the size of the imaging sensor.

The objective of this research is to advance the state of the art in compact 360 degree optics with a goal of achieving small mirror diameters, keeping ultra high resolution across the entire field of view. In the Phase I effort, to better understand the limitations of optics size we analyzed the underlying cause of the problem and derived a direct relationship between the mirror surface and the shape of the resulting image surface. Further analysis resulted in a novel approach for optimizing mirror shapes to achieve high resolution imagery in a compact form factor. This resulted in an overall size reduction to about 1/8th of the total volume, with no impact on the performance of the system. Two examples were designed to illustrate the approach.

Contributions within Discipline:

In this project, we have identified and demonstrated the design approaches and techniques necessary to advance the state of the art in ultra wide angle mirror based optical system to achieve significant improvements in size and scale relative to the current state of the art. We believe that development of products based on this concept will lead to a significant increase in the adoption of high resolution ultra wide angle video camera systems as this approach helps in eliminating one of key customer compromises in these systems.

 Contributions Beyond Science and Engineering:

The products developed using this significant advance in our design approach will expand the available market for ultra wide angle cameras. Small optics that cover a 360 degree field of view are unobtrusive and can be used for a variety of different commercial and defense applications. RemoteReality plans to incorporate this design approach in all of its optical platforms used for applications such as video conferencing, surveillance and situational awareness for defense.
